yearPlan.name: Daisy Petals Year
yearPlan.desc: This Daisy Year Plan is laid out in 15 meetings to help girls learn how to keep the Girl Scout Promise by living the Girl Scout Law, and earn the 10 petals that make the Daisy Flower. Daisies can also earn a Financial Literacy leaf, Cookie Business leaf, and a Take Action award.

meetingInfo.name: Space Science Explorer 1
meetingInfo.agenda: [1^As Girls Arrive/Snack^10][2^Opening Ceremony^5][3^Explore the Sun^20][4^Activity Choice Descriptions^10][5^Take Action Pause^5][6^Closing Ceremony^10]

multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Healthy snack items: fruit (strawberries, blueberries, cherries, apples, oranges, bananas), granola bars, crackers, carrot sticks, graham crackers, sliced cucumber and yogurt dip, juice, goldfish, and similar foods
  • Paper
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, etc.

Steps

Have each girl draw a picture of her favorite thing to do when the Sun is out.
multiactivities.materials:
• Healthy snack items: fruit (strawberries, blueberries, cherries, apples, oranges, bananas), granola bars, crackers, carrot sticks, graham crackers, sliced cucumber and yogurt dip, juice, goldfish, and similar foods
  • Paper
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, etc.

multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

Welcome the girls to the first Space Science Explorer badge meeting, and have them gather in a circle.

Girls say the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law together.

SAY:

  • When you came in you drew a picture of your favorite thing to do when the Sun is out. What activity did you pick? Why is it your favorite? 
  • Let's act them out! All at once--show me your favorite thing to do when the Sun is out.

Once the girls have the wiggles out, SAY:

  • Those are great activities! Now let's sit back down in our Daisy Circle.
  • Today we're going to learn more about the Sun, and, as we earn this badge, we are going to explore the Moon and stars as well. 
  • What is one thing you already know about the Sun? 
  • What is something you want to learn more about?

multiactivities.name: Make a Day Sky Book
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Sun
  • Paper (at least four sheets per girl)
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc.
  • Stapler or simple binding materials
  • Lamp with removable shade
  • Stickers

Steps

Pass out a sticker to each girl. Then, take your lamp, remove the shade, turn it on, and place it in the center of the room. Turn down the lights and SAY:

  • Everyone place your sticker on your nose.
  • Let's use our imagination! Pretend this lamp is the Sun, our heads are Earth, and the sticker on your nose is where you live. Turn this way (left) slowly and see if you can make it nighttime on your nose. What about daytime? What would sunrise/breakfast time look like? Or sunset/dinnertime? Which way would you be facing? Make a prediction (guess) just like a scientist. Let's explore, experiment, and test our predictions (guesses). Space scientists do this every day and now it's your turn!

If you have a large troop, be sure each girl is able to see the light--they may need to trade positions so that each can have a turn. Once the girls have had a chance to explore, SAY:

  • Have any of you ever heard the words "sunrise" and "sunset"?
  • That's how we describe the Sun coming up in the morning (sunrise) and going down at night (sunset). Did you know that the Earth is spinning like a top, and that's why the Sun looks like it's going across the sky? The same way you were spinning, the Earth does a complete spin every day, and that is what makes the Sun look like it's moving.
  • When our side of Earth is facing the Sun, it's daytime. When our side of Earth is facing away from the Sun, it's nighttime.

Once the girls have had a chance to discuss what they've discovered, SAY:

  • Next we are going to look at the sky and draw what we see--JUST like a scientist!
  • Let's start by making a day sky book.

Pass out paper, pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc. Then, SAY:

  • First let's decorate the cover of our day sky book. Be creative. Your day sky book should represent something special about you.

Once the girls have finished, SAY:

  • Now we're going to go outside, look up at the sky, and draw what we see.
  • Bring a piece of paper and some art supplies with you. REMEMBER: Do not look directly at the Sun. To do that, we'd need special tools called filters that protect our eyes.

Take the girls outside and have them draw what they see. If the weather keeps you from going outside, have them look out the window. SAY:

  • What do you see?
  • Are there any clouds? If so, what shape are they?
  • Where is the Sun in the sky? What color is it?
  • What color is the sky? How many colors can you count?

After they've finished, SAY:

  • Now that you've drawn what you see in the sky, I want you to take your day sky books with you. When you are home, look up at the sky at different times of day--maybe after breakfast, in the middle of the day, or in the evening right before the Sun sets? Any time will work!
  • Before you look at the sky, be a good scientist and make a prediction (guess) for what you think it will look like. Then, go outside and check your predictions (guesses). 
  • Draw what you see!
  • Where you correct? What was different?
  • Scientists check their predictions (guesses) all the time--that's how they learn.
  • Be sure to bring your day sky books with you to our next meeting, and share your sky pictures. Sharing is an important part of being a scientist--I can't wait to hear what you discover. I wonder how yours will be different from your Girl Scout sister's.

Bind the girls' day sky books with them. You and your girls can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best for you and your troop.
multiactivities.materials:
• The Sun
  • Paper (at least four sheets per girl)
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc.
  • Stapler or simple binding materials
  • Lamp with removable shade
  • Stickers
multiactivities.subtitle: Look at the sky and draw what you see in your own day sky book

multiactivities.name: Make a Shadow Poster
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Sun
  • A roll of butcher paper (pre-cut pieces taller than each girl)
  • OR smaller pieces of paper and small toys, like dolls or trucks (enough for each girl)
  • Pencils
  • Tape
  • Lamp with removable shade
  • Stickers

Steps

Pass out a sticker to each girl. Then, take your lamp, remove the shade, turn it on, and place it in the center of the room. Turn down the lights and SAY:

  • Everyone place your sticker on your nose.
  • Let's use our imagination! Pretend this lamp is the Sun, our heads are Earth, and your nose is where you live. Turn this way (left) slowly and see if you can make it nighttime on your nose. What about daytime? What would sunrise/breakfast time look like? Or sunset/dinnertime? Which way would you be facing? Make a prediction (guess) just like a scientist. Let's explore, experiment, and test your predictions (guesses). Space scientists do this every day and now it's your turn! 

If you have a large troop, be sure each girl is able to see the light--they may need to trade positions so that each can have a turn. Once the girls have had a chance to explore, SAY:

  • Have any of you ever heard the words "sunrise" and "sunset"?
  • That's how we describe the Sun coming up in the morning (sunrise) and going down at night (sunset). Did you know that the Earth is spinning like a top, and that's why the Sun looks like it's going across the sky? The same way you were spinning, the Earth does a complete spin every day, and that is what makes the Sun look like it's moving.
  • When our side of the Earth is facing the Sun, it's daytime. When our side of the Earth is facing away from the Sun, it's nighttime.

Once the girls have had a chance to discuss what they've discovered, SAY:

  • Throughout the day, as the Sun seems to move across the sky, what are some of the things you notice? What changes?
  • Have you ever noticed how the Sun changes your shadow?
  • Today, we are going to do an experiment! We are going to guess how our shadows will change as the Earth spins and the Sun looks like it's moving in the sky.

Pass out the sheets of butcher paper, pencils, and tape to each girl--then go outside!

If you chose to use smaller pieces of paper and small toys, like dolls or trucks, trace the objects' shadows instead of the girls'.

Once outside, SAY:

  • Help your fellow Girl Scout tape her sheet of paper to the ground.
  • If you're having a hard time, see if you can find some rocks to keep your paper in place. After we've finished with them, remember to put the rocks back where you found them!

After their paper is secure, SAY:

  • Pair up with one of your troop members.

NOTE: If you don't have an even number, make groups of three!

  • One girl should stand at the edge, facing her piece of paper, while the other girl traces her shadow. (OR: Place your small toy at the edge of the paper, while your partner traces its shadow.)
  • We're going to come back to our posters in a little bit. When we do, you'll want to stand in the same place. So, be sure you trace your partner's shoes--this way you'll remember where they were standing. 
  • When you're finished, switch and do the same for your partner!
  • Write the time on the paper next to your shadow.

Once everyone has their shadow traced, SAY:

  • We're going to leave your shadow tracings here, and come back at the end of the meeting. When we come back, we'll look to see if your shadows have changed.
  • Do you have any predictions (guesses) for what might happen to your shadows?
  • As scientists, it's important to make predictions (guesses), test them to see if they are right, and then share what you learned.

Optional: If you have time, have your girls play shadow tag as they wait for the Sun to move. Otherwise, continue with the meeting and have the girls test their predictions during the closing ceremony.
multiactivities.materials:
• The Sun
  • A roll of butcher paper (pre-cut pieces taller than each girl)
  • OR smaller pieces of paper and small toys, like dolls or trucks (enough for each girl)
  • Pencils
  • Tape
  • Lamp with removable shade
  • Stickers
multiactivities.subtitle: Trace your shadow and discover how it changes with the Earth's movement

multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Activity Choice Descriptions

Steps

SAY:

  • To earn a badge, each Girl Scout Daisy must complete three steps. Each step has two activity choices. For our first meeting, I made the activity choice I thought you girls would enjoy the most, but, for our next meeting, you'll get to decide what we do!

Walk your girls through the activity choices and let them decide which ones they like best. Be sure to have them choose an alternative activity in case the weather doesn't cooperate.

If there's an activity that doesn't seem doable for your troop, help them understand why. Maybe they have a solution you haven't thought of yet!

Materials

  • Paper
  • Pencils

Steps

SAY:

  • As Girl Scouts it's important that we Discover, Connect, and Take Action in order to make the world a better place. It's part of our Girl Scout Law!
  • As we continue our troop year, we're going to discuss some ways we can take action in our community.
  • Let's brainstorm a few ideas now.
  • I'll take notes, and, then, as we get closer to the end of the year, I'll remind you of your ideas. Once we have all your great ideas in one place, we can pick one and do that for our Take Action project.

Be sure to write down the girls' Take Action ideas throughout the year.

You'll use this list later in your troop year to remind the girls of their ideas and help them choose one to complete.

Materials

  • Space Science Bios

Steps:

Have the girls gather in a circle.

SAY:

  • Today you explored like scientists! One of the most important parts of being a scientist is sharing what you know. Can any of you share with me something that you discovered today?
  • What was your favorite part about today's troop meeting?
  • What is one thing you learned about the Sun?
  • When you go home, be a good scientist and share with your friends and family some of the discoveries you made with your Girl Scout sisters.

 

If you chose Make a Day Sky Book, SAY:

  • Don't forget to bring your Day Sky Books back with you to our next meeting so you can be good scientists and share what you saw. I wonder how yours will be different from your Girl Scout sister's.

If you chose Make a Shadow Poster, SAY:

  • Let's go outside and test our shadow predictions!

Take the girls outside and SAY:

  • Find your shadow poster and stand in the same place you did before--facing your paper. Look for the outline of your shoes to make sure you're standing in the exact same place.
  • Do you see any difference? What is different?
  • Were your predictions (guesses) correct? If not, how were your predictions (guesses) different?
  • Why do you think your shadow is different?
  • Just like a scientist, let's make more predictions (guesses).
  • Do you think your shadow would look different if we came back in an hour?
  • What about three hours?

Share with the girls your favorite part of the troop meeting.

SAY:

  • I am so proud of all of your scientific discoveries today. You were exploring, making predictions, and sharing just like real scientists. Before we leave, I am going to tell you about a real life space scientist who was once a girl just like you. 

Read your girls a bio, and show them a picture from the Space Science Bios handout.

Have the girls choose a song to sing to end your time together.

overview.str:
Note to Volunteers:

The excitement of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes be overwhelming. For that reason, scripting is included to help. These "lines" are under the heading "SAY;" however, you're the expert. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Your girls may ask you things that you don't know--that's ok! Tell them that asking questions is part of being a good scientist. Brainstorm ways you can work together to find the answers. It's also possible that no one knows yet--maybe your girls will grow up to discover them!

Three Steps/Two Choices per Step

Each Daisy must complete three steps in order to earn her Space Science Explorer badge. Each step has 2 activity choices. We suggest that you choose the first activity, and ask your girls to help decide the rest.

Prepare Ahead

General: Talk to anyone helping you about what they will do at this meeting.

General: Review Women in Space Science to familiarize yourself with resources that can help your girls learn more about women's roles in STEM fields.

Opening Ceremony: If you or your girls need it, print out copies of the Girl Scout Promise and Law.

Explore the Sun: The resource, The Sun, was developed especially for volunteers. Familiarize yourself with the facts and definitions to help you lead your girls through the activities in this badge.

Make a Day Sky Book: If it's easier for you, create and bind the girls' day sky books before the meeting. You can punch holes and tie the pages together with string or staple them--whatever works best.

Make a Shadow Poster: This activity works best on a clear day when the Sun is in the sky. If the weather keeps you from going outside, consider choosing a different activity.

Make a Shadow Poster: Cut sheets of butcher paper (taller than each girl) for all of your troop members, OR use smaller pieces of paper (enough for each girl).

Activity Choice Descriptions: Review the Activity Choice Descriptions ahead of time. Prepare any materials you need to help the choosing process come to life for your girls.

Closing Ceremony: Print out a copy of Space Science Bios.

Get Help from Your Friends and Family Network

See if anyone wants to lead or support an activity or meeting.

Award Connection

Space Science Explorer Badge

Space scientists are people who study outer space--what's in the sky. Just like a space scientist, girls will explore and observe the Sun, Moon and stars as they look at the sky and talk about what they see!

Steps:

1.     Explore the Sun

2.     Observe the Moon

3.     Meet the Stars

In this session, girls begin activities toward earning the Space Science Explorer badge.

They will earn their badge after completing activities at the end of the second Space Science Explorer meeting.

Meeting Length

60 minutes

The times given for each activity will vary, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the suggested time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!
